reasoning: The critique targets the claim that linear unbounded views are fussy because the distribution of value-efficiency across resource uses is fat-tailed. This is one component of the argument about linear views (Section 3.2), which is itself one branch of a multi-pronged argument spanning unbounded, bounded, and uncertainty considerations. Even if the fat-tailed distribution claim were undermined, the paper's broader argument about linear views still relies on the requirement to use nearly all accessible resources (the scale requirement across 20 billion galaxies), and the paper's conclusions about bounded views and moral uncertainty would remain intact. So centrality is moderate-to-low. The critique's strength is quite low because (1) the paper explicitly acknowledges theoretical reasons for expecting fat tails and notes that mere uncertainty about fat-tailedness produces fat-tailed expected distributions (a robustness argument the critique doesn't address), (2) the suggestion that technology might change the distribution is speculative and undeveloped — the critique provides no mechanism or argument for why technological change would compress rather than extend fat tails, and (3) the paper's argument doesn't depend on the distribution being permanently fixed; it depends on there being at any given time a very specific best use of resources among an astronomical space of possibilities. Correctness is middling: it's true that distributions can shift with technology, but the implication that this would reduce fussiness is unsupported and may be wrong (new technologies could make the distribution even more fat-tailed). Clarity is moderate — the point is understandable but vague about what 'shifts' would look like and why they'd help. The critique is focused on a single issue.
title: Evolving value-efficiency distributions could undermine linear view fussiness
